utterances: It's like the double edged sword situation.
You don't want that kind of thing being said about your own candidate.
It's one thing to say that about someone else that you're running against.
But you know, is anybody ever ready to be president?
She's being honest.
I understand what she's saying.
But at the same time, again, I step back into that communication director role, you don't want that kind of stuff out there.
And you know, this kind of goes back to a larger issue.
People continue to forget that, and you know, I'm an independent.
But Barack Obama has had a lot of experience at the state level in the state legislature.
I mean again, you're talking about someone who was the commander in chief's wife.
Let's put this in perspective.
â€¦when it comes to disaster operations.
They had just about the same amount of time in the Senate but he has a lot of legislative experience, and that counts for something.
That's one of the things that Michael Dukakis was talking about.
So - and him, himself having a lot of experience in the legislature et cetera, so...
Before we wrap this up, in general it sounds like advisors really only get a lot of play if they've done something that doesn't really fall into the oh-this-was-great column.
It's only when they get in trouble that we hear about them.
Kym, does that seem right to you?
It doesn't really seem right to me.

I think that, you know, some of the policy decisions that a candidate makes or some of the great things that have come out of their campaign should be credited to the advisors that have been working with them.
But again, you know, the bad publicity gets the attention.
And that's pretty typical but troubling.
I want to move on to Fisk University.
That college, historically black college, boasts some stellar alums, including W.E.B.
Du Bois and Nikki Giovanni.
But the national school is also strapped for cash.
They were trying to sell valuable works by American painter Georgia O'Keeffe.
That collection was estimated at more than $100 million, but a Nashville judge squashed the sales plan.
Fisk is officially forbidden from selling any of the pieces.
Harry, part of the deal that O'Keeffe made with Fisk when she donated the collection was that Fisk wouldn't sell the pieces and the work would remain on display.
Talk about the display issue in a minute.
But if the work now belongs to Fisk and if Fisk really needs the money, why shouldn't the agreement with O'Keeffe be re-evaluated?
Should it be re-evaluated at any point?
Well, that's a really good question.

I have a colleague, a good colleague by the name of Ray Winbush(ph) who is now at Morgan State operating their Center for Black Studies there, but he used to be at Fisk running the Race Relations Institute, and we were talking about this subject.
And he calls the deal that Charles Johnson, who was president in the '40s when the donation was made, a deal with the devil.

He compares it to someone being given a brand new Rolls Royce on the condition that they could never drive it, would have to keep it in a warm garage, wash it once a month, wax it four times a year and keep it insured.
And it's a wonderful car.
It's one of the most, you know, incredible marks every made, but you can't do anything with it and eventually it starts to drain on you.
And his position is that when O'Keeffe made this deal, it was really almost like what she was trying to do was irritate the New York art world.
Kind of like saying I have the Stieglitz collection, I can do whatever I want with it.
In fact I'm going to give it to these black people just so you guys won't have it, just to show you what I can do.
And on one hand it's great to have, you know, one of the most valuable collections of the 20th Century.
But on the other hand, it's becomes quite, it's become, I wouldn't say an albatross but it's certainly become a hard thing for them to manage.

And when I was speaking with Ray, he said that he felt that in the '60s or '70s, when Fisk was a bit more secure financially, they should have gone to court and said that the initial deal was made under racial duress and used that as a way of getting out of this or renegotiating the terms of the agreement.
Kym, when you hear Harry outlining all of these different stipulations and the back story of it, do you expect that at any point Fisk could go back to the table and ask for a re-negotiation?
Or by this all playing out in court at this point is it pretty much a done deal?
I think they should absolutely go back to court.

And I was under the impression that the gift was made in two segments, and the first segment by Alfred Stieglitz was under the condition that they could never sell it, and then the second set of gifts by Georgia O'Keeffe didn't have that same stipulation.
And I'm sure if they parse it apart and are in perhaps a less desperate situation, they'll have more power in court or the ability to negotiate that.
But it's just to me - it's just so troubling that this collection has become a burden for Fisk.
And what if, you know, in 100 years, Fisk no longer exists?
What happens to the collection?
It doesn't really...
The Santa Fe Museum gets it.
Yeah, there's definitely...

So it's just a matter of, you know, keeping it on display and having this, you know, historic black college and the students look at this artwork instead of having it be, you know, a collateral or something, the ability to get money or make money from it.
Well, you know, it's interesting.
I think - not to interrupt you, Kym - this is kind of like a metaphor for much of the state of black America, like incredible, precious gifts but insufficient infrastructure to manage them.
And then those things often, sometimes work against us or don't work in our favor or work for other people.

Robert, when you listened to this case, do you think that it resonates with the larger issues of how historically black colleges and universities, despite having great alums, despite having a lot of support, just don't have a lot of the time these fundamental - if you think about schools like Harvard and Yale and plenty of other schools, there are these multi-billion-dollar endowments, and things are running pretty thin for a lot of HBCUs.
What could turn that around?
They are, and what needs to happen and what we have to be very cognizant of within the black community is that we need to make sure that we give back to the schools that gave so much to us.
I think it's a sad day when we have schools like Fisk that are in danger, schools like FAMU that are in danger in financial status.
But let me just say one of the things that is important here.
Race is an issue in terms of this collection and the way it was handed down.
But black schools have to realize - because I have covered this extensively as a reporter, with attorney Melvin Gibbs and the William H.

Johnson case of artwork, he's been litigating for some time against people like Fisk, people like Tuskegee, people like the Smithsonian, talking about you have to follow a chain, the appropriate chain of ownership.
You cannot just do what you want with this artwork when you get it, and I think there was an element of that with Fisk.
They thought they could do this, and reading the agreement, they can't.
There are some restrictions here.
So they have to follow the letter of the law until they can get the law on their side.
I would hope that our memories aren't so short that what we saw in Newtown isn't lingering with us, that we don't remain passionate about it only a month later.
I want to pop in.
In case anyone is just tuning in to us, this is NPR's NEWS & NOTES.
I'm Farai Chideya.
We were just hearing from Robert Redding, who publishes the ReddingNewsReview.com.
Also we've got the media assassin, Harry Allen, who blogs at HarryAllen.info, and Kym Platt, who blogs at AskThisBlackWoman.com.
So I will ask this black woman about pop culture in politics.
You know, the pundits and the pollsters get their glory during the campaign season.
So do the comedy shows, and SNL, ""Saturday Night Live,"" has taken on Clinton and Obama.
A couple of weekends ago, the New York senator popped on to the ""Saturday Night Live"" set, and here she is opposite SNL's Amy Poehler, who plays Clinton on the show.
(Soundbite of television show, ""Saturday Night Live"")
(Soundbite of applause)
(As herself) How are you?
(As Hillary Clinton) Good, thank you.
(As herself) Well, I'm glad to be here.
Thanks for having me.
(As Clinton) Oh, thank you for coming.
I love your outfit.
(Soundbite of laughter)
(As herself) Well, I love your outfit.
(As Clinton) Why, thank you.
(As herself) But I do want the earrings back.
(As Clinton) (Laughing) Oh, okay.
(Soundbite of laughter)
(As herself) Do I really laugh like that?
Yeah, well, all right, then.
So it was all fun and giggles, but some people feel that SNL has actually been favoring Clinton.
They've done a sketch that we talked about on the show on a previous day that basically implies that Obama has been getting a free pass from the press.
What do you think, Kym?
Do you think that this is a situation where SNL or other outlets could actually influence the election?
I think they can influence, because the American public is - can be influenced.
And I think, you know, you said SNL is taking on Barack and Hillary.
I think they're actually just taking on Barack.
And last Saturday, this past Saturday, there was the skit where, you know, Barack Obama has a 3 a.m. phone call, and he actually calls Hillary Clinton and asks for advice.

So I think they've really come out and declared Hillary as their candidate of choice without, you know, so much as saying they are endorsing her, and they're doing it with humor, and humor's very powerful, and I think people can be influenced.
Harry, does that sound as if it's - SNL has chosen sides?
I don't really think so.
I think Hillary's the bigger target.
I think that she's bigger and easier, in a way, to make fun of.

And I have to admit the thing that I found most striking watching the sketch that you just played audio from - and I also had this reaction when I was watching her appearance on Jon Stewart's show - was for the moment I was watching her, I actually found myself liking her.
Like I just found myself, like, connecting to her.
And this must have been, I guess, the way many white women felt when they saw her cry.
But I actually saw myself liking her just for the moment I saw her there with her timing and her humor.
She seemed very natural and at ease, you know, in a way that she doesn't come off when she's, you know, I guess spouting policy.
Robert, is there anyplace else that you turn - for example ""The Daily Show"" is a news-comedy hybrid.
What other places do you think are really influential right now, just a couple of them?
In terms of the Mosh Pit?
Yup.
Well, of course, ""The Colbert Report."" It's definitely one of the shows that's at the top of the list.
So outside of that, I really don't know of many other shows, because I don't even watch those, you know, for a political hard-edged stuff.
That's why I thank God for NPR.
(Soundbite of laughter)
